messageBody:
It seems to me that some, though perhaps not all, aspects of Senior QS
could serve as an aid to reading a long text. Consider the word "end".
Not only is it a common word, but it comprises a letter sequence that
occurs frequently in the beginning, middle and end of longer words
(e.g. endurance, commendable, trend). As I have argued before, a word
such as "end" would look quite strange if written with #23 instead of
alt-#23, and I further contend that the alternates for #23 and #36
should be included in Junior QS. So the proper spelling (using revised
names) would be Ed+Noon+Deed. Now, once you begin to use half-letters,
it becomes immediately natural to use half-Deed in "end":
Ed+Noon+half-Deed. This quickly becomes a recognizable unit in longer
words. It would take experimentation to prove it, but my guess is that
this particular combination would only improve reading speed and
comprehension.

I think it will take experimentation on a case-by-case basis to
determine the best mix of Senior and Junior QS to use in printed text.
In the meantime, I would hate to see us discourage the use of Senior
QS in advance. Let's give writers everything they need to make their
own choices. Over time, readers will express preferences and stylistic
guidelines will emerge.

Ted


On Jan 12, 2008 10:15 PM, peter_r_guinness <malt99@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I've been thinking about alternative and half letters in my
> proposal. I've come to the conclusion that I shouldn't include the
> alternative nor half letters within the 7 bit ACSII range. eg: I
> would not map them to the latin lower nor uppercase letters. These
> letters, I would place in the extended ACSII range. By placing them
> there it deliberately makes it more difficult for people to type
> them thus discouraging people from using these letters. (Note: I
> would still map the letters for "ks", "gz", loch and llan to the
> latin letters. Since there is only one grapheme for these letters.)
>
> I donot support the use of alternative letters for typed text for
> the following reasons:
> -most people would be too lazy to type the alternatives instead they
> would just use the one form. This has happened with traditional
> orthography once the strict formal requirement for capitalization of
> letters at the start of sentences is relaxed- eg: in less formal
> communications such as phone texting or internet messaging where
> people choose to use only the lower case.
> -causes inconsistency in typed text. Some people would use junior,
> some a combination of junior and senior while others (I think very
> few though) would use true senior.
> -slows down typing until all the various letter combinations that
> occur have been learnt. ie: Initially have to pause and think which
> alternative to use before it becomes automatic to type
> -if quikscript was ever to become widely popular and printed
> material was published in quikscript I would be very surprised if
> publishers used senior. This is due to the fact that fluent reading
> of senior script requires further learning and more practise than
> junior. I image that publishers would publish text in the junior
> version so that could be read by the greatest number. I'm an
> example of this, I can read junior fluently but have not bothered to
> learn senior.
> -the junior looks more uniform and neat than the senior when typed
> (well it does to me anyway).
>
> If people do want to produce or read senior text, than this would
> best be achieved by using software to convert typed junior (or a
> junior/senior mix) into true senior (or a specific mix of
> junior/senior). Software would produce a more consistent and
> accurate senior text than manual methods.
>
> If some people really do want to type the senior alternatives
> regularly they could use a keyboard mapping* that maps an "alt-gr"
> keypress combined with the junior key for the letter. Eg: half-poe
> would then be typed "alt-gr"+"p".
>
> I feel that senior is best left for advanced handwriting and junior
> for typed text.
>
> *Just to clear up terminology a bit.
> The term "keyboard mapping" has not been used correctly all the time
> in the group here (I've personally been very guilty of this). What
> have been doing and discussing is applying ASCII/Latin1 character
> codes to the quikscript graphemes.
> A keyboard mapping maps actual keys/key-press-combinations on the
> keyboard to character codes.
>
>
